part.title: Add licensing statements
part.para: The RES crawler is responsible for harvesting data from a publisher's Linked Data site. The data it harvests is then ingested, transformed and re-published as an openly-licensed index. For this to work, the data must be licensed in a way which enables re-purposing; and statements about the licensing must be accessible to the RES crawler in the data itself.
Returning to RES's four main categories of resource, the following types of licensing statement can be applied:

listitem.para: Documents must have licensing statements. Without these, RES won't be able to index them.

Real-world things typically don't need licensing: it's impossible to copyright a person or building, for example, so there's no need to license their reuse. (Though a person's name or building design could be copyrighted.)
Creative works usually have licensing; for example, the copyright on a novel or photograph defines who can reproduce it. However, RES doesn't need to know about this to crawl the data.

Digital assets often have licensing; for example, copyright on a digital file allows reuse in specific contexts. (Usually, the copyright of a digital file matches the creative work or other resource which it represents.) Again, RES doesn't need to know about this to crawl the data.

part.para: The crawler only needs licensing statements on the data documents. Licensing on other resources may be included in the index after crawling, but isn't necessary for the data to be crawled.

note.para: If your digital assets can't be openly published or reused (e.g. they should only be used in educational contexts or in the UK), you will need to protect them yourself. The standard approach to doing this is to implement authentication or similar constraints in a player, then embed the digital asset inside that.

section.para: A licensing statement for a resource has this general form:

The resource URI is the URI of the resource for which you are specifying the licence; this will usually be a document, but could be a creative work or digital asset. The licensing predicate and licence URI are explained in the next two sections.

section.title: Licence URIs
section.para: The licence URI should refer to a well-known open licence from the list below.

tip.para: If you wish to use another licence, it should adhere to the principles of the Open Definition. You will also need to let the RES team know about the licence so the RES crawler can be configured to recognise it.

section.title: Adding licences to the museum's data
section.para: The museum needs to license its documents and their formats. It chooses the Open Government Licence Version 3 (OGL v3).
The museum's photograph and its JPEG representation are licensed under the Creative Commons CC BY 3.0 licence.

As the museum is already using the DC Terms vocabulary, it decides to use dcterms:license to associate the licences with their resources, which is one of the licensing predicates the RES crawler can recognise.
Their licensing statements look like this:
